questions.question: Which country is shown in this map?
questions.explanation: The triangular peninsula extending into the Indian Ocean with a northeast corridor identifies India. [web:1][web:15]

questions.explanation: An arc-shaped archipelago of four main islands and Hokkaido to the north identifies Japan. [web:1][web:15]

questions.explanation: A vast outline with a pronounced northeastern extension toward the Korean Peninsula marks China. [web:1][web:15]

questions.explanation: The large, roughly rectangular landmass occupying most of the Arabian Peninsula is Saudi Arabia. [web:1][web:15]

questions.question: Which country is shown in this map?

questions.explanation: A west‚Äìeast diagonal outline on the subcontinent‚Äôs northwest with a narrow coastal south marks Pakistan. [web:1][web:15]

questions.question: Which country is shown in this map?
questions.explanation: A teardrop-shaped island off India‚Äôs southeast coast is Sri Lanka. [web:1][web:15]

questions.explanation: A long, narrow east‚Äìwest stretch nestled along the Himalayas identifies Nepal. [web:1][web:15]

categories.name: World Inventors & Inventions
categories.description: Greatest inventors and groundbreaking inventions that changed the world

questions.question: Who invented the telephone?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell patented the first practical telephone in 1876.

questions.question: Who discovered penicillin?
questions.explanation: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928, revolutionizing medicine.

questions.question: Who invented the X-ray?
questions.explanation: Wilhelm Roentgen discovered X-rays in 1895 and won the first Nobel Prize in Physics.

questions.question: Who developed the theory of relativity?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein developed both special and general theories of relativity.

questions.question: Who invented the microscope?
questions.explanation: Zacharias Janssen is credited with inventing the compound microscope around 1590.

questions.question: Who discovered radioactivity?
questions.explanation: Henri Becquerel discovered radioactivity in 1896, though Marie Curie named the phenomenon.

questions.question: Who invented the telescope?
questions.explanation: Hans Lippershey is credited with inventing the first telescope in 1608.

questions.question: Who discovered the electron?
questions.explanation: J.J. Thomson discovered the electron in 1897 through his cathode ray experiments.

questions.question: Who invented the lightning rod?
questions.explanation: Benjamin Franklin invented the lightning rod in 1752 after his famous kite experiment.

questions.question: Who developed the periodic table?
questions.explanation: Dmitri Mendeleev created the first periodic table of elements in 1869.

questions.question: Who invented the laser?
questions.explanation: Theodore Maiman built the first working laser in 1960, though the concept was developed by others.

questions.question: Who discovered DNA structure?
questions.explanation: Watson, Crick, and Franklin all contributed to discovering DNA's double helix structure.

questions.question: Who invented the radio?
questions.explanation: Guglielmo Marconi is credited with developing the first practical radio communication system.

questions.question: Who invented the television?
questions.explanation: Television was developed by multiple inventors, with Baird, Farnsworth, and Zworykin making key contributions.

questions.question: Who invented the printing press?
questions.explanation: Johannes Gutenberg invented the movable-type printing press around 1440 in Europe.

questions.question: Who invented the transistor?
questions.explanation: Bardeen, Brattain, and Shockley jointly invented the transistor at Bell Labs in 1947.

questions.question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
questions.explanation: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web while working at CERN in 1989.

questions.question: Who co-invented the integrated circuit?
questions.explanation: Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce independently invented the integrated circuit in 1958-59.

questions.question: Who invented the computer mouse?
questions.explanation: Douglas Engelbart invented the computer mouse in 1964 at Stanford Research Institute.

questions.question: Who invented the fax machine?
questions.explanation: The fax machine evolved through contributions from Bain (1843), Caselli, and others.

questions.question: Who invented the phonograph?
questions.explanation: Thomas Edison invented the phonograph in 1877, the first device to record and reproduce sound.

questions.question: Who developed Morse code?
questions.explanation: Samuel Morse and Alfred Vail developed Morse code for use with the telegraph.

questions.question: Who developed the first successful vaccine?
questions.explanation: Edward Jenner developed the first vaccine for smallpox in 1796.

questions.question: Who invented the stethoscope?
questions.explanation: Ren√© Laennec invented the stethoscope in 1816 to listen to heart and lung sounds.

questions.question: Who developed the polio vaccine?
questions.explanation: Jonas Salk developed the injectable polio vaccine (1955) and Albert Sabin the oral vaccine (1961).

questions.question: Who performed the first heart transplant?
questions.explanation: Christiaan Barnard performed the first human heart transplant in South Africa in 1967.

questions.question: Who discovered insulin?
questions.explanation: Banting, Best, and Macleod discovered insulin at the University of Toronto in 1921-22.

questions.question: Who invented anesthesia for surgery?
questions.explanation: Multiple doctors contributed to developing surgical anesthesia in the 1840s.

questions.question: Who discovered the blood circulation system?
questions.explanation: William Harvey described blood circulation in 1628, though Ibn al-Nafis described pulmonary circulation earlier.

questions.question: Who developed the CT scan?
questions.explanation: Godfrey Hounsfield and Allan Cormack jointly won the Nobel Prize for developing CT scanning.

questions.question: Who invented the artificial heart?
questions.explanation: Multiple inventors contributed to artificial heart development, with Jarvik-7 being most famous.

questions.question: Who developed the MRI scanner?
questions.explanation: MRI was developed through contributions from Damadian, Lauterbur, and Mansfield.

questions.question: Who invented the automobile?
questions.explanation: Karl Benz created the first practical automobile with internal combustion engine in 1885.

questions.question: Who invented the airplane?
questions.explanation: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first powered flight at Kitty Hawk in 1903.

questions.question: Who invented the steam engine?
questions.explanation: Thomas Newcomen invented the first practical steam engine in 1712; Watt improved it significantly.

questions.question: Who built the first successful steamboat?
questions.explanation: Robert Fulton built the first commercially successful steamboat, the Clermont, in 1807.

questions.question: Who invented the bicycle?
questions.explanation: Karl Drais invented the first bicycle-like vehicle called the 'draisine' in 1817.

questions.question: Who invented the locomotive?
questions.explanation: Richard Trevithick built the first steam locomotive in 1804, though Stephenson made them practical.

questions.question: Who invented the helicopter?
questions.explanation: Igor Sikorsky built the first practical helicopter, the VS-300, in 1939.

questions.question: Who invented the jet engine?
questions.explanation: Frank Whittle (Britain) and Hans von Ohain (Germany) independently invented jet engines.

questions.question: Who invented the submarine?
questions.explanation: Cornelis Drebbel built the first navigable submarine in 1620, though others improved the design.

questions.question: Who built the first rocket to reach space?
questions.explanation: Wernher von Braun's V-2 rocket was the first to reach space in 1944, though Goddard pioneered liquid fuel rockets.

questions.question: Who is considered the father of the computer?
questions.explanation: Charles Babbage designed the Analytical Engine, considered the first general-purpose computer design.

questions.question: Who wrote the first computer program?
questions.explanation: Ada Lovelace wrote the first computer algorithm for Babbage's Analytical Engine in 1843.

questions.question: Who invented the first electronic computer?
questions.explanation: Multiple inventors contributed to early electronic computers, including ENIAC and Atanasoff-Berry Computer.

questions.question: Who founded Microsoft?
questions.explanation: Bill Gates and Paul Allen co-founded Microsoft in 1975.

questions.question: Who founded Apple Computer?
questions.explanation: Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne co-founded Apple Computer in 1976.

questions.question: Who invented the computer compiler?
questions.explanation: Grace Hopper created the first compiler, A-0 System, in 1951.

questions.question: Who invented the programming language C?
questions.explanation: Dennis Ritchie developed the C programming language at Bell Labs between 1969-1973.

questions.question: Who founded Google?
questions.explanation: Larry Page and Sergey Brin founded Google while PhD students at Stanford in 1998.

questions.question: Who founded Facebook?
questions.explanation: Facebook was co-founded by Zuckerberg, Saverin, Moskovitz, and Chris Hughes at Harvard.

questions.question: Who invented the computer graphics chip (GPU)?
questions.explanation: Huang, Malachowsky, and Priem co-founded NVIDIA and pioneered modern GPU technology.

questions.question: Who invented email?
questions.explanation: Ray Tomlinson sent the first network email and introduced the @ symbol for addresses in 1971.

questions.question: Who created the Linux operating system?
questions.explanation: Linus Torvalds created the Linux kernel in 1991 while studying at University of Helsinki.

categories.name: GK World
categories.description: Test your knowledge about the world

questions.question: Who was the first President of the United States?
questions.explanation: George Washington was the first President of the United States (1789‚Äì1797).

questions.question: Who was the first President of India?
questions.explanation: Dr. Rajendra Prasad served as the first President of India (1950‚Äì1962).

questions.question: In which year did India gain independence?
questions.explanation: India became independent on 15 August 1947.

questions.question: Who was known as the 'Iron Man of India'?
questions.explanation: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel is called the 'Iron Man of India' for his role in unifying the princely states.

questions.question: Who founded the Maurya Empire?
questions.explanation: Chandragupta Maurya established the Maurya Empire with guidance from Chanakya.

questions.question: The Dandi March (Salt March) was led by whom?
questions.explanation: Gandhi led the Salt March in 1930 to protest the salt tax.

questions.question: The Battle of Plassey was fought in which year?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Plassey was fought in 1757 between the British East India Company and Siraj-ud-Daulah.

questions.question: Who was the founder of the Mughal Empire in India?
questions.explanation: Babur founded the Mughal Empire in 1526 after the First Battle of Panipat.

questions.question: The Quit India Movement was launched in which year?
questions.explanation: The Quit India Movement was launched by Gandhi on August 8, 1942.

questions.question: Who was the last Viceroy of India?
questions.explanation: Lord Mountbatten was the last Viceroy of India (1947) and the first Governor-General of independent India.

questions.question: The Indus Valley Civilization was discovered in which year?
questions.explanation: Harappa, the first site of Indus Valley Civilization, was discovered in 1921 by Dayaram Sahni.

questions.question: Who established the Chola Empire?
questions.explanation: Vijayalaya Chola founded the medieval Chola Empire in 848 CE.

questions.question: The Jallianwala Bagh massacre took place in which year?
questions.explanation: The Jallianwala Bagh massacre occurred on April 13, 1919, in Amritsar.

questions.question: Who was known as 'Netaji'?
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandra Bose was popularly known as 'Netaji' and founded the Indian National Army.

questions.question: The Simon Commission arrived in India in which year?
questions.explanation: The Simon Commission arrived in India in 1928 and was boycotted as it had no Indian members.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Discovery of India'?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru wrote 'Discovery of India' while imprisoned in Ahmednagar Fort (1942-1946).

questions.question: The Revolt of 1857 started from which place?
questions.explanation: The Revolt of 1857 began in Meerut on May 10, 1857.

questions.question: Who was the first Indian woman to become President of Indian National Congress?
questions.explanation: Annie Besant was the first woman president of INC in 1917.

questions.question: The Battle of Haldighati was fought between?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Haldighati (1576) was fought between Akbar's forces and Maharana Pratap.

questions.question: Who gave the slogan 'Jai Hind'?
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandra Bose popularized the slogan 'Jai Hind' as a greeting for the Indian National Army.

questions.question: The Khilafat Movement was led by?
questions.explanation: The Ali Brothers (Mohammad Ali and Shaukat Ali) led the Khilafat Movement (1919-1924).

questions.question: What is the southernmost point of India (mainland)?
questions.explanation: Kanyakumari is the southernmost point of mainland India; Indira Point is the southernmost point of the Indian territory (Nicobar).

questions.question: Which is the largest state in India by area?
questions.explanation: Rajasthan is the largest state by area (342,239 sq km).

questions.question: Which river is known as the 'Sorrow of Bihar'?
questions.explanation: Kosi River is called the 'Sorrow of Bihar' due to frequent floods.

questions.question: Which is the highest mountain peak in India?
questions.explanation: Kangchenjunga (8,586 m) is the highest peak located entirely within India.

questions.question: The Thar Desert is primarily located in which state?
questions.explanation: Most of the Thar Desert lies in Rajasthan.

questions.question: Which is the longest river in India?
questions.explanation: Ganga is the longest river in India with a length of 2,525 km.

questions.question: How many states share border with Bangladesh?
questions.explanation: Five states share border with Bangladesh: West Bengal, Tripura, Meghalaya, Mizoram, and Assam.

questions.question: Which Indian state has the longest coastline?
questions.explanation: Gujarat has the longest coastline of about 1,600 km.

questions.question: The Tropic of Cancer passes through how many Indian states?
questions.explanation: Tropic of Cancer passes through 8 states: Gujarat, Rajasthan, MP, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, WB, Tripura, and Mizoram.

questions.question: Which is the smallest state in India by area?
questions.explanation: Goa is the smallest state with an area of 3,702 sq km.

questions.question: Chilika Lake is located in which state?
questions.explanation: Chilika Lake, Asia's largest brackish water lagoon, is in Odisha.

questions.question: Which Indian state is known as 'Land of Five Rivers'?
questions.explanation: Punjab means 'Land of Five Rivers' - Sutlej, Beas, Ravi, Chenab, and Jhelum.

questions.question: The Western Ghats are also known as?
questions.explanation: The Western Ghats are also known as Sahyadri Mountains.

questions.question: Which is the largest coffee producing state in India?
questions.explanation: Karnataka produces about 70% of India's coffee.

questions.question: The Sundarbans Delta is formed by which rivers?
questions.explanation: The Sundarbans is formed by the Ganga-Brahmaputra delta system.

questions.question: Which Indian state is the largest producer of tea?
questions.explanation: Assam produces more than 50% of India's tea.

questions.question: The Palk Strait separates India from which country?
questions.explanation: The Palk Strait separates Tamil Nadu (India) from Sri Lanka.

questions.question: Which is the wettest place in India?
questions.explanation: Mawsynram in Meghalaya receives the highest rainfall in India.

questions.question: The Narmada river flows into which body of water?
questions.explanation: Narmada flows westward and drains into the Arabian Sea.

questions.question: Which Indian city is known as the 'Silicon Valley of India'?
questions.explanation: Bengaluru is known as the Silicon Valley of India due to its IT industry.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with Fundamental Rights?
questions.explanation: Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12‚Äì35).

questions.question: The Directive Principles of State Policy are borrowed from the constitution of which country?
questions.explanation: DPSPs were inspired by the Irish Constitution.

questions.question: How many schedules are there currently in the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: There are 12 schedules after successive amendments.

questions.question: Who appoints the Chief Justice of India?
questions.explanation: The President appoints the CJI, typically following the collegium's recommendation.

questions.question: What is the minimum age to be a member of the Rajya Sabha?
questions.explanation: Minimum age is 30 years for Rajya Sabha membership.

questions.question: The Constitution of India was adopted on?
questions.explanation: The Constitution was adopted on 26 November 1949 and came into effect on 26 January 1950.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Father of Indian Constitution'?
questions.explanation: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is known as the Father of Indian Constitution.

questions.question: The maximum strength of Lok Sabha is?
questions.explanation: Maximum strength of Lok Sabha is 552 (530 states + 20 UTs + 2 Anglo-Indian).

questions.question: The President of India can be impeached on grounds of?
questions.explanation: The President can be impeached only for 'violation of the Constitution'.

questions.question: Which Article deals with the abolition of Untouchability?
questions.explanation: Article 17 abolishes untouchability and its practice in any form.

questions.question: The Preamble declares India to be?
questions.explanation: The Preamble declares India as a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic, Republic.

questions.question: Who has the power to declare a National Emergency?
questions.explanation: The President can declare National Emergency under Article 352.

questions.question: The Right to Information Act was passed in which year?
questions.explanation: The RTI Act was passed in 2005 to promote transparency in governance.

questions.question: The minimum age for becoming the Prime Minister of India is?
questions.explanation: PM must be a member of Lok Sabha (min age 25) or Rajya Sabha (min age 30).

questions.question: How many Fundamental Rights are there in the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: There are 6 Fundamental Rights after the 44th Amendment removed Right to Property.

questions.question: The concept of 'Basic Structure' of the Constitution was given in which case?
questions.explanation: The Kesavananda Bharati Case (1973) established the Basic Structure doctrine.

questions.question: The 73rd Amendment Act deals with?
questions.explanation: The 73rd Amendment (1992) provides constitutional status to Panchayati Raj institutions.

questions.question: Who can remove the Vice President of India?
questions.explanation: Vice President can be removed by a resolution passed by Rajya Sabha and agreed by Lok Sabha.

questions.question: The Union List contains how many subjects?
questions.explanation: The Union List currently contains 98 subjects (originally 97).

questions.question: Which Article provides for freedom of speech and expression?
questions.explanation: Article 19(1)(a) provides for freedom of speech and expression.

questions.question: Which classical dance form originated in Kerala?
questions.explanation: Kathakali is a classical dance-drama from Kerala known for elaborate costumes and makeup.

questions.question: The Ajanta Caves are located in which state?
questions.explanation: The Ajanta Caves are Buddhist cave monuments in Maharashtra dating from 2nd century BCE.

questions.question: Who wrote the national anthem 'Jana Gana Mana'?
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore composed Jana Gana Mana, adopted as national anthem in 1950.

questions.question: The Konark Sun Temple is located in?
questions.explanation: The 13th-century Konark Sun Temple in Odisha is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

questions.question: Which is the oldest Veda?
questions.explanation: Rig Veda is the oldest of the four Vedas, composed around 1500 BCE.

questions.question: The famous 'Hornbill Festival' is celebrated in which state?
questions.explanation: The Hornbill Festival is celebrated in Nagaland every December.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Nightingale of India'?
questions.explanation: Sarojini Naidu was called the 'Nightingale of India' for her poetry.

questions.question: The Khajuraho temples were built by which dynasty?
questions.explanation: The Chandela dynasty built the Khajuraho temples between 950-1050 CE.

questions.question: Bihu is the folk dance of which state?
questions.explanation: Bihu is the folk dance of Assam performed during the Bihu festival.

questions.question: The Taj Mahal was built by which Mughal Emperor?
questions.explanation: Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.

questions.question: Which musical instrument did Pandit Ravi Shankar play?
questions.explanation: Pandit Ravi Shankar was a world-renowned sitar maestro.

questions.question: The Ellora Caves represent which religions?
questions.explanation: Ellora Caves have Buddhist, Hindu, and Jain monuments built between 600-1000 CE.

questions.question: Pongal is the harvest festival of which state?
questions.explanation: Pongal is the harvest festival celebrated in Tamil Nadu in January.

questions.question: The famous Meenakshi Temple is located in?
questions.explanation: The Meenakshi Amman Temple is a historic Hindu temple in Madurai, Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which is the national flower of India?
questions.explanation: Lotus (Nelumbo nucifera) is the national flower of India.

questions.question: The Reserve Bank of India was established in which year?
questions.explanation: RBI was established on April 1, 1935, based on the recommendations of the Hilton Young Commission.

questions.question: What does GST stand for?
questions.explanation: GST (Goods and Services Tax) was implemented in India on July 1, 2017.

questions.question: Which Five Year Plan is known as 'Gadgil Yojana'?
questions.explanation: The Fourth Five Year Plan (1969-74) is known as Gadgil Yojana after D.R. Gadgil.

questions.question: NITI Aayog replaced which organization?
questions.explanation: NITI Aayog replaced the Planning Commission on January 1, 2015.

questions.question: The Green Revolution in India was led by?
questions.explanation: M.S. Swaminathan is known as the Father of Green Revolution in India.

questions.question: Which sector contributes the most to India's GDP?
questions.explanation: The services sector contributes around 55-60% to India's GDP.

questions.question: The Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana was launched in?
questions.explanation: PM Jan Dhan Yojana was launched on August 28, 2014, for financial inclusion.

questions.question: India's first stock exchange was established in?
questions.explanation: Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) was established in 1875.

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Father of White Revolution' in India?
questions.explanation: Verghese Kurien led Operation Flood, making India the largest milk producer.

questions.question: The Indian rupee symbol (‚Çπ) was adopted in which year?
questions.explanation: The Indian rupee symbol was adopted on July 15, 2010.

questions.question: India won its first Cricket World Cup in which year?
questions.explanation: India won its first Cricket World Cup in 1983 under Kapil Dev's captaincy.

questions.explanation: Milkha Singh was nicknamed the 'Flying Sikh' for his achievements in athletics.

questions.explanation: P.V. Sindhu won silver at the 2016 Rio Olympics in women's singles badminton.

questions.question: The national game of India is?
questions.explanation: India has no officially declared national game, though hockey is often considered as one.

questions.explanation: Abhinav Bindra won India's first individual Olympic gold in 2008 Beijing (10m Air Rifle).

questions.explanation: Sachin scored his 100th international century against Bangladesh in 2012.

questions.explanation: C.V. Raman won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1930 for the Raman Effect.

questions.question: The father of Indian Space Program is?

questions.question: Which IIT was established first?

questions.question: India's first indigenous aircraft carrier is named?

questions.question: The BrahMos missile is jointly developed by India and which country?

categories.name: Indian Inventions
categories.description: Indian inventors, scientists and their groundbreaking discoveries

questions.question: Who invented the concept of zero?
questions.explanation: Brahmagupta (628 CE) first gave rules for computing with zero and negative numbers.

questions.question: The decimal system was invented by?
questions.explanation: The decimal system including place value notation was developed in ancient India.

questions.question: Who calculated the value of pi (œÄ) accurately?
questions.explanation: Madhava of Sangamagrama calculated œÄ to 11 decimal places in the 14th century.

questions.question: The game of chess originated in which ancient Indian kingdom?
questions.explanation: Chess (originally Chaturanga) was invented during the Gupta Empire around 6th century CE.

questions.question: Who wrote the ancient surgical text 'Sushruta Samhita'?
questions.explanation: Sushruta wrote the Sushruta Samhita, describing over 300 surgical procedures.

questions.explanation: Bhaskara II discussed the concept of infinity in his work Lilavati.

questions.question: Who invented cataract surgery?
questions.explanation: Sushruta performed the first cataract surgery and described the procedure.

questions.explanation: Pingala described binary numbers in his work on Sanskrit prosody around 200 BCE.

questions.explanation: Aryabhata calculated Earth's circumference as 24,835 miles, very close to the actual 24,902 miles.

questions.explanation: Sushruta Samhita describes plastic surgery techniques including rhinoplasty.

questions.question: Who invented the flush toilet system?
questions.explanation: The Harappan civilization had sophisticated sewage and water management systems.

questions.question: Who wrote the Yoga Sutras?

categories.name: Literature & Arts
categories.description: Indian authors, novels, poetry, and literary achievements

questions.question: Who wrote the epic 'Ramayana'?
questions.explanation: Maharishi Valmiki is credited with writing the original Sanskrit epic Ramayana.

questions.question: The 'Mahabharata' was written by?
questions.explanation: Ved Vyasa is traditionally credited as the author of the Mahabharata.

questions.explanation: Kalidasa wrote 'Abhijnana Shakuntalam', considered one of the greatest Sanskrit dramas.

questions.question: The 'Arthashastra' was written by?
questions.explanation: Kautilya (also known as Chanakya) wrote the Arthashastra, an ancient treatise on economics and politics.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Ramcharitmanas'?
questions.explanation: Tulsidas wrote Ramcharitmanas, an Awadhi version of the Ramayana.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Gitanjali'?
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore wrote 'Gitanjali', for which he won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913.

questions.question: The novel 'Anandmath' was written by?
questions.explanation: Bankim Chandra Chatterjee wrote 'Anandmath', which contains the song 'Vande Mataram'.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Godan'?
questions.explanation: Munshi Premchand wrote 'Godan', considered one of the greatest Hindi novels.

questions.question: The God of Small Things was written by?
questions.explanation: Arundhati Roy wrote 'The God of Small Things', which won the Booker Prize in 1997.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Midnight's Children'?
questions.explanation: Salman Rushdie wrote 'Midnight's Children', which won the Booker Prize in 1981.

questions.question: The novel 'Train to Pakistan' was written by?
questions.explanation: Khushwant Singh wrote 'Train to Pakistan', a novel about the partition of India.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Kamayani'?
questions.explanation: Jaishankar Prasad wrote 'Kamayani', considered the greatest epic in modern Hindi literature.

questions.question: The novel 'Coolie' was written by?
questions.explanation: Mulk Raj Anand wrote 'Coolie', a novel about the exploitation of the working class.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Chemmeen' in Malayalam?
questions.explanation: Thakazhi Sivasankara Pillai wrote 'Chemmeen', which won the Sahitya Akademi Award.

questions.question: Who wrote 'Parva' in Kannada?
questions.explanation: S.L. Bhyrappa wrote 'Parva', a modern retelling of the Mahabharata in Kannada.

questions.question: The Marathi novel 'Shyamchi Aai' was written by?
questions.explanation: Sane Guruji wrote 'Shyamchi Aai', a beloved Marathi novel about a mother's love.

questions.explanation: Qurratulain Hyder wrote 'Aag Ka Darya', considered a masterpiece of Urdu literature.
